name: TheAtlantic
text: Flesh-eating bacteria are on the rise in the beach towns near Melbourne, Australia, and scientists are struggling to figure out why, @bborrell reports. https://t.co/dVVFBbK8CJ

name: TheAtlantic
text: Flesh-eating bacteria are on the rise in the beach towns near Melbourne, Australia, and scientists are struggling to figure out why, @bborrell reports. https://t.co/sTob8gyWKE

name: TheAtlantic
text: The Supreme Court on Thursday granted Alabama’s request to restore voting restrictions, including efforts that may limit absentee voting during the pandemic. @AdamHSays examines how voter suppression will affect the November election. https://t.co/l8BtD3Totz

name: TheAtlantic
text: The coronavirus pandemic is one reason Iowa's sleepy Senate race is suddenly one to watch, @elainejgodfrey writes. https://t.co/4NTIwtyv0h

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I ran away from institutional racism; I cannot watch while my adopted country moves toward it now," Hirsh Goodman writes: https://t.co/jycNdbFO0U

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Baldwin put his whole life and body weight into these words, which, today more than ever, reverberate like a never-ending nightmare." Raoul Peck, the director of "I Am Not Your Negro," writes about heeding James Baldwin, more than 50 years later: https://t.co/UIlg1url3b

name: TheAtlantic
text: “The way many think of custodial staff does not reflect the value that they provide to hospitals," @RepMarkTakano told @jasper_craven recently. “They are critical to infection control; we need to see these employees as skilled workers.” https://t.co/xL0KTgW7aT

name: TheAtlantic
text: This year, the Fourth of July is being greeted with mixed feelings. Here’s our guide to observing this strange day. The latest Atlantic Daily, by @mimbsy and @haleysweiss: https://t.co/t4hHV1AkYs

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: @jameshamblin and @katlwells talk about air conditioners, toilet plume, and how to limit your exposure to the coronavirus indoors. https://t.co/gILTE6kMJ0

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Advance directives are one of the most important gifts people can give to their loved ones before they die. But few people actually have them in place," Joel Rowe writes. https://t.co/1Bl22S7REL

name: TheAtlantic
text: There exists a quiet network of Black pastors and staffers who serve as unofficial racism consultants to the white evangelical world, @emmaogreen reports: https://t.co/USTHq1tUQY

name: TheAtlantic
text: "COVID-19 has provided an agonizing reminder: Life is precious. Life is short," @Ken_Budd writes: https://t.co/5FzaqkLf5Q

name: TheAtlantic
text: "My heart and blood recede / but my electrics seem to be in love / ceaselessly conversing. / I don’t agree to this hallucination. / I like the decadent / privacy of text / but a part of it feels mistaken." https://t.co/jCmtHr3uWv

name: TheAtlantic
text: "When will the protests end? And what will it mean when they do? Although all waves of mass protest are different, they tend to follow a similar course," @markjengler writes: https://t.co/u8b77hZyPC

name: TheAtlantic
text: Black faces have long been considered a threat by American law enforcement. Facial-recognition technology poses a major threat to Black people, @culturejedi writes. https://t.co/pJMEs8hZPA

name: TheAtlantic
text: Real revolutions are a surprise, @RebeccaSpang writes. "Revolutions happen when the distinct concerns of many different groups are for a time more or less soldered together—and this coming together is … produced largely by chance." https://t.co/gCUxhrtXSL
